metadata./Keywords: Iridodialysis; Extended depth of focus (EDOF) intraocular lens (IOL); Cataract surgery; Traumatic posterior subcapsular cataract
metadata./Title: Visual outcome after monocular implantation of extended depth of focus intraocular lens in a patient with iridodialysis: a case report and literature review
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background: Background Iridodialysis, the separation of the iris root from the ciliary body, typically
sections.Results:
results from trauma and can 
lead to significant visual impairment. This case report is novel as it demonstrates the successful management of irido dialysis using an extended depth of focus intraocular lens in a patient with a slightly irregular pupil.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 34-year-old Hispanic man presented with reduced vision and pain in his right eye following blunt trauma from a nail at work. Examination revealed a small temporal corneal stromal scar, traumatic posterior 
subcapsular cataract, two inferior iridodialysis defects, and a superiorly displaced dyscoric oval pupil. Snellen uncor rected distance visual acuity was 20/400. The patient opted for an extended depth of focus intraocular lens implantation to meet his visual demands for distance and intermediate vision without glasses. Cataract surgery with capsular 
tension ring, extended depth of focus intraocular lens implantation, iridodialysis repair, and suture pupilloplasty 
were performed uneventfully. At 1 month postoperatively, uncorrected distance visual acuity improved to 20/40, 
while uncorrected intermediate visual acuity and uncorrected near visual acuity were 20/20. A central, relatively 
round, and slightly inferiorly peaked pupil was achieved. A steroid response intraocular pressure rise at postoperative 
month 2 required intraocular pressure-lowering medications, and symptomatic posterior capsular opacity developed 
at 8 months postoperatively. At 11 months postoperatively, selective laser trabeculoplasty and laser capsulotomy 
were performed. At 4-year follow-up, visual acuity measurements remained stable, and intraocular pressure was nor mal without any medication. The patient was satisfied with the visual and cosmetic outcomes.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This case demonstrates that extended depth of focus intraocular lenses can be a viable option 
for patients with slightly irregular pupils following suture repair of the iris and pupil. The successful visual and cosmetic outcomes in this patient suggest that extended depth of focus intraocular lenses may be considered in similar 
complex cases, providing a balance of near, intermediate, and distance vision without significant visual disturbances.
Keywords  Iridodialysis, Extended depth of focus (EDOF) intraocular lens (IOL), Cataract surgery, Traumatic posterior 
subcapsular cataractOpen Access

Page 2 of 6 Tran et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:545 
Background
Iridodialysis is the separation of the iris from its attach ment to the ciliary body caused by a rupture at the iris 
root [1–3]. Small iridodialysis defects can be asympto matic, but for larger iridodialysis defects, patients may 
experience diplopia, glare, photophobia, and cosmetic 
issues, and in these cases surgical repair is indicated [2–
5]. Iridodialysis often occurs secondary to blunt ocular 
trauma, penetrating ocular trauma, or intraocular sur gical procedures [1–3, 6]. These causes can also lead to 
other ocular comorbidities, such as elevated intraocular 
pressure (IOP), microhymphema, and traumatic cata racts [7, 8]. Among these, the diagnosis of traumatic cata racts can be particularly challenging. Visualization of the 
traumatic cataract may be obscured by blood, fibrin, and 
debris in the anterior chamber [6, 9, 10]. Furthermore, 
the pupil may be small and difficult to dilate [9, 10]. Eyes 
with iridodialysis pose additional challenges intraopera tively and postoperatively owing to their irregular pupil 
shape, impaired pupillary response, possible zonulopathy, 
and risk of glaucoma owing to previous trauma or angle 
recession [9–11]. Extra steps to reconstruct the anterior 
segment, such as iris and pupil suture repair, or iris pros thesis, may be required at the time of cataract surgery.
The development of multifocal intraocular lenses 
(MIOLs) and extended depth of focus (EDOF) intraocu lar lenses has allowed for greater spectacle independ ence among patients with cataract with presbyopia and 
patients undergoing refractive lens exchange. Given the 
wide variety of MIOLs and EDOF IOLs available, their 
optics and their respective impact on the patient’s qual ity of vision and quality of life must be fully understood 
and reviewed before choosing the appropriate intraocu lar lens (IOL) for each patient.
It is well understood that the visual performance of 
intraocular lenses (IOLs) is dependent on pupil size [12–
14]. Therefore, the potential benefit of presbyopia cor recting IOLs is less predictable in patients with impaired 
pupil response alongside irregular pupil shape. Multifo cal IOLs utilize changes in pupil size to maintain focus 
across various distances and lighting conditions [15].
Newly developed IOLs aim to have lens performance 
be independent of pupil size. The development of EDOF 
technology has led to novel presbyopia correcting lens 
implants which have demonstrated good visual outcomes 
across a range of distances, with high levels of specta cle independence and patient satisfaction [16]. How ever, the safety and effectiveness of EDOF IOLs have not 
been substantially studied in patients with preexisting 
ocular conditions, such as iridodialysis or pupil defects 
[17]. Novel EDOF technology is stated to provide stable 
performance in any lighting condition [17] but no spe cific data have been published regarding the extent of its pupil dependence and its impact on visual outcomes in 
patients with irregular pupil shape.
We hereby present a case with monocular iridodialysis 
with a limited pupillary response and traumatic cataract, 
in which excellent visual outcome was achieved after iri dodialysis repair, suture pupilloplasty, and monocular 
implantation of an extended depth of focus IOL with a 
capsular tension ring after cataract extraction.
Case presentation
Examination findings
Initial visit
On 12 May 2016, a 34-year-old Hispanic man presented 
with reduced vision and pain in his right eye following 
blunt trauma from a nail at work. The patient’s past med ical and ocular history was otherwise unremarkable. Ini tial examination revealed an uncorrected distance visual 
acuity of hand motion in the right eye and 20/15 in the 
left eye. His intraocular pressure (IOP) was elevated at 
24 mmHg in the right eye and was normal at 20 mmHg in 
the left eye. The right pupil was atonic, appeared oval and 
fixed at 3 × 4 mm, with no relative afferent pupil defect. 
Slit lamp biomicroscopy showed a 3 mm superficial par tial thickness laceration in the inferotemporal cornea, 
trace corneal edema, and central 5  mm oval epithelial 
defect on the right cornea. There was also a 3  mm epi thelial defect at the limbus inferiorly. The anterior cham ber was deep with 4 + red blood cells, and the lens was 
clear. Two small iridodialysis defects were seen inferiorly 
in the right iris. Left anterior segment was unremarkable. 
Optic disc appeared normal with cupping 0.3–0.4 in the 
right, and 0.3 in the left. Retinal commotio was noted in 
the right macula, but retina seemed flat; the view was 
hazy owing to the corneal and anterior chamber finding 
stated above. The left fundus was unremarkable. Full vis ual potential was uncertain. He was advised to keep his 
head elevated while sleeping. Gatifloxacin (Zymar, Aller gan Inc., Markham, Ontario), dexamethasone (Maxidex, 
Novartis, Basel, Switzerland), atropine, and brimonidine 
(Alphagan, AbbVie Corporation, St-Laurent, Quebec) 
were started.
Follow ups
At his initial follow-up, on 13 May 2016, his corneal abra sion had healed. His visual acuity improved to 20/100 
but his IOP rose to 34  mmHg with microhymphema 
still present. Dexamethasone was increased to every 
2  h while awake and 5% sodium chloride (Muro 128, 
Bausch  + Lomb, New Jersey, USA) four times a day was 
added for the persistent corneal edema. Brinzolamide 
and timolol (Azarga, Novartis, Basel, Switzerland) com bination eye drop and bimatoprost (Lumigan, Allergan 
Inc., Markham, Ontario) were added to control IOP .
Page 3 of 6
 Tran et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:545 
 
The patient was seen for routine follow-up to stabi lize IOP , subdue anterior chamber reaction and resolve 
microhyphema in the right eye. By 17 November 2016, 
only trace pigment cells remained in the anterior cham ber. The corneal partial thickness laceration and lim bal abrasion both healed unremarkably. Subsequently a 
traumatic cataract in the right eye developed. Cataract 
surgery was planned once IOP stabilized and anterior 
chamber reaction subsided. At 6 months after the initial 
visit, the patient was seen for a preoperative assessment. 
There was a 3 + anterior and posterior subcapsular cata ract present with an uncorrected vision of 20/400 in the 
right eye. The patient was on brinzolamide and timolol 
combination eye drops for the right eye and intraocular 
pressure was 21 mmHg. A small 2.2 m linear corneal scar 
was present temporally in the right cornea secondary to 
initial trauma, with two iridodialysis defects inferiorly; 
one at the inferotemporal quadrant and the other at the 
inferonasal quadrant. Only a few pigments but no cell 
was present in the anterior chamber. Angles remained 
wide open. Optic disc cupping remained 0.4 in the right 
eye with a flat retina. The remainder of the ocular exam 
was unremarkable.
Right eye biometry with IOL Master 500 (Carl Zeiss 
Meditec, Jena, Germany) revealed an axial length of 
23.16  mm, corneal curvature (K1) 43.55 D @ 165°, and 
(K2) 44.18 D @ 75° (corneal cylinder 0.63 D). Anterior 
chamber depth (ACD) was 3.63  mm, white-to-white 
(WTW) distance was 12.2 mm, and pupil diameter was 
4.7 mm. The patient was stable to undergo cataract sur gery with iridodialysis repair of the right eye.
Explanation for IOL choice
The risks and benefits of cataract surgery, iridodialy sis repair, and iris suturing, along with IOL options, 
were thoroughly discussed with the patient. Choosing a 
monofocal lens would pose a dilemma for patient’s life style: targeting distance vision would compromise near 
vision, which was critical for the patient’s occupation and 
depth perception. Conversely, focusing on near vision 
would impair distance sight. To mitigate anisometropia 
and maintain balanced near and far vision, a multifocal 
or extended depth of focus (EDOF) IOL was deemed 
necessary, despite the potential for postoperative halos 
and glare, which are usually transient. The patient opted 
to have the Tecnis Symfony® IOL (Johnson & Johnson 
Vision Care, Inc., Santa Ana, California, USA) in his right 
eye.
Description of the procedure
Cataract surgery
Informed consent was obtained from the patient. Patient 
opted to have surgery done under general anesthesia owing to the duration of the case. The right eye under went phacoemulsification and posterior chamber intracapsular IOL implantation. To facilitate the process, 
three additional inferior paracenteses were created, and 
iris hooks were employed to manage the atonic pupil 
during cataract removal. Notably, inferior zonular weak ness was addressed by placing a type 14c capsular tension 
ring in the capsule bag to ensure lens stability. A 22.5 D 
Tecnis Symfony® IOL (ZXR00) was inserted.
Iridodialysis repair
After completion of the cataract surgery portion of the 
case, Miochol-E (Bausch & Lomb Incorporated, Bridge water, New Jersey, USA) was injected in the anterior 
chamber to achieve miosis. However, owing to previous 
trauma, only partial miosis was achieved. Iridodialysis 
repair was performed using a double arm needle-docking 
maneuver to close both the inferotemporal and inferona sal iridodialysis defects. A suture loop was created using 
10–0 polypropylene (Ethicon Inc., Raritan, New Jersey, 
USA) to close each iridodialysis. Each polypropylene 
suture was secured using a 3-1-1 simple interrupted tying 
technique, and the knot was subsequently buried within 
one of the sclerostomies.
Suture pupilloplasty
A teardrop-shaped pupil, peaking inferiorly after iridodi alysis repair, necessitated suture pupilloplasty using three 
simple-interrupted 10–0 polypropylene sutures with 
intraocular tying techniques using microforceps (Micro Surgical Technology, Redmond, Washington, USA) to 
achieve a relatively round central pupil. There was trace 
aqueous outflow at the inferonasal sclerotomy, thus to 
prevent hypotony 30% Viscoat (Alcon Laboratories, Inc., 
Fort Worth, Texas, USA) was retained in the eye after 
all other viscoelastics were removed. 10–0 nylon (Ethi con Inc., Raritan, New Jersey, USA) sutures were placed 
to close each incision to ensure watertight closure. The 
peritomy was closed with 7–0 vicryl (Ethicon Inc., Rari tan, New Jersey, USA) and 8–0 vicryl (Ethicon Inc., Rari tan, New Jersey, USA) sutures in simple interrupted and 
horizontal mattress fashions. A bandage contact lens was 
applied owing to tendency for aqueous egress from infe ronasal sclerostomy. Postoperative management included 
500  mg of acetazolamide orally to prevent IOP rise. 
The patient tolerated the procedure well under general 
anesthesia.
Postoperative
Early post-operative visits were uneventful with gradually 
resolving anterior chamber reaction.
At the 10-month post-operative follow-up assessment, 
the eye was treated with YAG laser capsulotomy owing 
Page 4 of 6 Tran et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:545 
to symptomatic posterior capsule opacification (uncor rected distance visual acuity declined from 20/40 to 
20/60) and with selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) to 
control intraocular pressure and reduce glaucoma medi cation use. At 22-month postoperative follow-up, the 
patient was treated with a repeat SLT laser in the right 
eye.
At the final 4-year post-operative follow-up, patient 
expressed high satisfaction with the results and reported 
no issues with either distance or near-vision activities 
with the right eye. Uncorrected distance Snellen visual 
acuity was 20/40 in and uncorrected intermediate and 
near visual acuity was 20/20. The patient did not com plain of any significant glare from his uncorrected dis tance visual acuity. His intraocular pressure remained 
normal at 18  mmHg for the right eye. The eye did not 
show any signs of corneal decompensation. Optical 
coherence tomography of the macula showed no evi dence of cystoid macular edema. Iris sutures remained 
intact and pupil shape remained stable, central and rela tively round (Fig.  1). The patient was discharged back to 
his optometrist for routine monitoring.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Pupil abnormalities can significantly affect visual qual ity. Blunt ocular trauma can lead to traumatic miosis or 
mydriasis, impairing the ability to regulate light entry and 
thus visual acuity [7, 17]. Iridodialysis is detachment of 
the iris root from ciliary muscles and is associated with 
a decentered pupil and limitation in pupil size adjust ment, resulting in photic symptoms, such as glare, and 
adversely affects visual quality in varying light conditions 
[18–21]. Fixed pupil sizes, either too small or too large, 
compromise visual clarity or cause optical distortions owing to inadequate or excessive retinal illumination. 
Thus, repairing iridodialysis can notably improve visual 
outcomes by restoring pupil position and functional ity and may combine with cataract surgery, as demon strated by existing literature [2, 3, 6, 22, 23]. This case 
underscores the potential benefits of iridodialysis repair 
for enhancing postoperative visual acuity in combination 
with cataract surgery.
Irregular pupil shapes disrupt normal light passage 
into the eye, leading to abnormal retinal illumination 
and optical aberrations, such as photophobia, glare, and 
diplopia, which degrade visual acuity [23, 24]. The nor mal pupil, a circular aperture, facilitates a distinct diffrac tion pattern crucial for sharp vision. Deviations from this 
shape produce irregular patterns, affecting visual qual ity [25]. Pupilloplasty, aimed at rectifying irregular pupil 
shapes, has shown to significantly mitigate these visual 
disturbances. Evidence suggests that combining pupil loplasty with cataract surgery enhances visual outcomes 
in patients with irregular pupils, including those with 
congenital uveal coloboma, by reducing the likelihood 
of postoperative glare and monocular diplopia [26]. Our 
case also supports the utility of pupilloplasty in improv ing postsurgical visual acuity and patient satisfaction.
Blunt ocular trauma necessitates multifaceted surgical 
interventions, including iridodialysis repair and pupillo plasty, in combination with extraction of traumatic cata ract with zonulopathy and IOL implantation [7, 8, 23, 
24]. This case exemplifies the critical need for a nuanced 
understanding of IOL options and tailored treatment 
strategies for patients with trauma-induced irregular 
pupil shapes and iris defects, ensuring optimal visual 
outcomes.
The advent of presbyopia-correcting IOLs transforms 
visual outcomes, offering patients spectacle-free correc tion for near, intermediate, and distance vision. These 
IOLs fall into two main categories: accommodative, 
which adjusts focus via ciliary muscle contraction [27], 
and multifocal, creating several focal points with distinct 
optical power zones [28].
Multifocal IOLs are subdivided into refractive and dif fractive types. Refractive IOLs, with their concentric 
zones, offer vision correction across all distances, though 
performance may vary with pupil size [29]. Diffractive 
IOLs, however, use a design that achieves pseudoaccom modation, effectively focusing light at multiple distances 
independently of pupil size, enhancing visual acuity con sistently [30].
The Tecnis Symfony® IOL, a diffractive lens, employs a 
unique diffraction pattern to extend the focal zone, offer ing an expanded range of vision that is independent of 
pupil size. This design aims to ensure consistent visual 
performance under different lighting conditions without 
Fig. 1 Postoperative image of the eye following cataract surgery, 
iridodialysis repair, and pupilloplasty, showing restored iris 
attachment and pupil shape
Page 5 of 6
 Tran et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:545 
 
relying on a multi-zone approach for focusing at various 
distances [15, 16]. However, empirical evidence on the 
extent of its pupil independence remains sparse.
Our clinic has previously reported excellent visual out comes after bilateral EDOF IOL implantation in a patient 
with bilateral iris microhemangiomas [31]. This case 
report illustrates that EDOF IOLs can be a reasonable 
option for cataract patients who suffer from iris vascular 
anomalies with limited pupillary response [31].
In patients with cataract with pupil abnormalities, 
including impaired pupil response or irregular pupil 
shape or iris defects, pupil-independent diffractive IOLs 
such as the Tecnis Symfony® offer a reliable solution. 
This report details a case where a patient with iridodial ysis and irregular pupil shape from blunt ocular trauma 
achieved excellent visual acuity over a range of distances 
with an EDOF IOL, without adaptation issues in varying 
light conditions. To our knowledge, this is the first case 
to underscore the efficacy of extended depth of focus 
(EDOF) IOLs in managing patients with cataract with 
complex pupil dynamics after iris suture repair, advocat ing for their consideration in similar clinical scenarios.
Abbreviations
UCDVA  Uncorrected distance visual acuity
EDOF  Extended depth of focus
IOL  Intraocular lens
UCIVA  Uncorrected intermediate visual acuity
UCNVA  Uncorrected near visual acuity
IOP  Intraocular pressure
SLT  Selective laser trabeculoplasty
MIOLs  Multifocal intraocular lenses
K1  Corneal Curvature (Keratometry) at 1st Meridian
K2  Corneal Curvature (Keratometry) at 2nd Meridian
ACD  Anterior chamber depth
WTW   White-to-White Distance

Consent for publication

this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent
